review.title: Comparative Study of View Update Algorithms in Rational Choice Theory
review.abstract: The dynamics of belief and knowledge is one of the major components of any autonomous system that should be able to incorporate new pieces of information. We show that knowledge base dynamics has interesting connection with kernel change via hitting set and abduction. The approach extends and integrates standard techniques for efficient query answering and integrity checking. The generation of hitting set is carried out through a hyper tableaux calculus and magic set that is focused on the goal of minimality. Many different view update algorithms have been proposed in the literature to address this problem. The present paper provides a comparative study of view update algorithms in rational approach.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: It is only a matter of time before there is a new information base that may become inconsistent. In argumentation theory, one tries to solve the same principle [5,13,14] in different contexts. Revision means modifying the knowledge base in order to maintain consistency [81] while maintaining the new information and the removal of contraction. In our case, revision means revision and contraction, i.e. insertion and deletion in the database. Revision means establishing links with the knowledge base [6,7].

sections.heading: 3 Knowledge base dynamics
sections.text: With regard to the logical structure of beliefs, they formulate eight postulates that a revision-based knowledge base must prove (contraction knowledge base was discussed in [7]). In the BI approach, a belief is represented by a sentence about a suitable language, and a belief KB is represented by a sentence that is close to the logical closing operator Cn. KB KB KB is assumed to be closed using the Boolean operators negation, conjunction, disjunction and implication. Definition KB is a knowledge base with an immutable part of KBI. Let KB and β be two clauses of LH.

sections.heading: 3.2 Generalized revision algorithm
sections.text: The problem of Knowledge Base Revision concerns determining how a request for change can be adequately translated into one or more atoms or dictionaries. In this section, we develop a new, generalized revision algorithm. Note that it is sufficient to calculate all KBI-locally minimum abduction explanations for KBI. Theorem 2. Let KB be a Horn Knowledge Base and α is formula. 1. If Algorithm 1 KBI 'is produced as a result of KB revision, KB' fulfills all rationality postulates (KB * 1) to (KB * 6) and (KB * 7.3). 2. sections.heading: 4 Deductive database
sections.text: A deductive database DDB consists of three parts: an intensive database IDB (KBI), a set of definitive program clauses, an extended database EDB (KBU), a set of soil factors, and a set of integrated ones. The intuitive meaning of DDB is demonstrated by the least herbrand semantics and all the tortures. The predicates defined in IDB are referred to as reference points for predicates and those defined in EDB. Extended this notion, an atom with an atom view, and similarly an atom with a base predicates. Furthermore, we assume that IDB contains no predicates and no predicates are defined.

sections.heading: 5.1 View update algorithm
sections.text: The key idea of the algorithm presented in this paper is to transform the given database into a disjunctive logic program, together with the request for an update of the view, and to apply well-known disjunctive techniques to solve the original problem of updating the view. Intuition behind the transformation is to obtain a disjunctive logic program in such a way that each (minimal) model of this transformed program represents a way to update the given view atom. We present two variants of our algorithm: one, discussed in this section, applies a trivial transformation procedure, but must look for minimum models; and the other performs a costly transformation, but does not calculate the minimum models.

sections.heading: 6 A Comparative Study of Integrity Constraints and View Update
sections.text: During the process of updating a database, two related issues could occur. On the one hand, if an update is applied to the database, integrity constraints may become incompatible with the request, then stop the process. On the other hand, if an update request consists of updating some derived predicates, a view update mechanism must be applied to translate the update request into correct updates of the underlying base factors. Our work does not focus on the approach of maintaining integrity. In this section, we expand Mayol and Teniente's [83] survey for updating and integrity constraint. The most important aspects that need to be taken into account during the process of updating and integrity constraint of the view are the following: enforcement of the problem is addressed, the permitted update requirements, the technology applied, update changes, and the solutions received by each of these six dimensions.

sections.heading: 7 Related Works
sections.text: It is indeed the case that we are able to set out in search of new paths to follow in order to achieve our objectives.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusion and remarks
sections.text: We argued for the generalization of belief dynamics theory in two ways: to treat certain parts of knowledge as immutable and to abandon the requirement that the belief must be deductively closed. We achieved the intended generalization by introducing the concept of knowledge base dynamics and generalized contraction for the same thing. Furthermore, we also investigated the relationship between knowledge base dynamics and abduction, which results in a generalized algorithm for revision. We also successfully demonstrated how knowledge base dynamics can provide an axiomatic characterization for updating an atom (literally) in order to update a stratifiable database. In bridging the gap between belief dynamics and viewpoint actualizations, we observed that a balance between computational efficiency and rationality must be achieved.

Though we have discussed only about view updates, we believe that knowledge base dynamics can also be applied to other applications such as view maintenance, diagnosis, and we plan to explore it further (see works [19] and [18]).

metadata.abstractText: The dynamics of belief and knowledge is one of the major components of any autonomous system that should be able to incorporate new pieces of information. We show that knowledge base dynamics has interesting connection with kernel change via hitting set and abduction. The approach extends and integrates standard techniques for efficient query answering and integrity checking. The generation of hitting set is carried out through a hyper tableaux calculus and magic set that is focused on the goal of minimality. Many different view update algorithms have been proposed in the literature to address this problem. The present paper provides a comparative study of view update algorithms in rational approach. Keyword: AGM, Belief Revision, Knowledge Base Dynamics, Kernel Change, Abduction, Hyber Tableaux, Magic Set, View update, Update Propagation.
